Label: <textile technique>
Scope note: Do not use this term as it is used purely as a way of grouping textile technique terms.

Label: alkaline glazed
Scope note: Term used to describe a common class of pottery produced in southern Iraq and south-west Iran during the early Islamic period but continuing a much longer local tradition. Typically coloured with copper oxides to produce green, blue or turquoise glaze on a pale yellow body but as the glaze is unstable it often weathers heavily.

Label: aquatint
Scope note: The term is a sub-variety of intaglio printmaking in which tone is created by etching around grains on resin.

Label: baked
Scope note: For Middle East this term is used to describe low temperature heating or accidental baking. It is distinct from firing (see 'fired'). The only exception is where this technique is used to describe the conservation treatment of cuneiform tablets which were previously unbaked (see Material 'clay').

Label: barbotine
Scope note: Used to describe plastic effects on the surface of a pottery vessel resulting from the manipulation of a slip. The Department of Greece and Rome also use the term as a ware, when the technique is found on Minoan Pottery

Label: barked
Scope note: Technique for preserving skins, involving submersion to leach fat, used North America.

Label: basse-taille
Scope note: The term 'enamel' should be entered as a Material.

Label: baxter process
Scope note: The term is a mixed variety of printmaking, patented by George Baxter in 1935, using multiple wood-engraved blocks printed in colour over an intaglio key-plate.

Label: beadwork
Scope note: Beads when strung upon a set of interconnected elements to form a panel or network.

Label: beni-e
Scope note: Japanese woodblock print with hand-coloured pink pigment.

Label: benizuri-e
Scope note: Early Japanese woodblock prints generally with two printed colours, pink (beni) and green, but also yellow, indigo and brown.

Label: bidri
Scope note: Enter ZINC ALLOY and SILVER in the Materials field.

Label: bitten
Scope note: Used for impressing design on e.g. birchbark in North America.

Label: bleached
Scope note: This term is restricted to intentional bleaching of textiles, cloths, skins, etc.

Label: block-printed
Scope note: Use for textiles, etc.; for prints, use alternative terms. Prehistory & Europe: use TRANSFER-PRINTED for tiles.

Label: blueprint
Scope note: The term is a variety of photographic process, in which a drawing on transparent paper is printed down onto paper prepared with iron salts which turn blue under the action of light.

Label: braided
Scope note: The term braided has been used in both a textile and non-textile context.

Label: brass-plated
Scope note: Enter BRASS in the Material field.

Label: cabochon cut
Scope note: The cabochon cut gives a facetless, domed form.

Label: cast
Scope note: Use SLIP-MOULDED for pottery objects.

Label: champlevé
Scope note: The term 'champlevé' is used in two contexts: enamelling and in ceramics. This second use of the term is referred to by 'champlevé' (pottery). For the simple term 'champlevé', the term 'enamel' should be entered as a Material.

Label: champlevé pottery
Scope note: The term 'champlevé' is used in two contexts: enamelling and in ceramics. This second use of the term is referred to by 'champlevé' (pottery).

Label: chattered
Scope note: Potter's term used to described the effect whereby a tool such as a wooden rib is held against the gently rotating pot to create a series of shallow vertical undulations on the body of the pot.

Label: chinkinbori
Scope note: Occurs on lacquer; the outline of a design is cut with thin lines and these are filled or partially filled with metal dust (usually gold or silver).

Label: chip-carved
Scope note: A carving technique also adapted to metal-casting to give metal surfaces a chiselled effect by use of a carved mould.

Label: chrisgrafia
Scope note: Method developed by Arent Lauri Christensen which employs oil varnish with sand or marble dust on aluminium or plastic plate to create the printing surface.

Label: chromium-plated
Scope note: Enter CHROMIUM in the Material field.

Label: chromolithograph
Scope note: This term is often confined to a variety of colour lithograph using multiple plates which are stippled to achieve the effect of continuous rather than flat tone. It is often more generally used for any lithograph printed in more than two colours. N.B. For lithographs printed in one or two colours, both Technique terms 'lithograph' and 'colour' are entered. For lithographs printed using tint stones (and no additional printed colour), only Technique 'lithograph' is entered.

Label: cloisonné enamelling
Scope note: The term 'cloisonné' is used in two contexts: enamelling and for the setting of garnets and other stones in cloisons on metalwork. This second use of the term is referred to by cloisonné (inlay). For the enamelling 'cloisonné', 'enamel' should be entered as a Material.

Label: cloisonné inlay
Scope note: The term 'cloisonné' is used in two contexts: enamelling and for the setting of garnets and other stones in cloisons on metalwork. This second use of the term is referred to by cloisonné (inlay).

Label: cold painted
Scope note: Painting on ceramics which has not been fired.

Label: cold-cut
Scope note: The term refers to a technique in the manufacture of glass objects.

Label: collagraph
Scope note: This term is for a print made from an inked printing surface that has had elements (usually odd-shaped pieces of metal) or objects fused to it

Label: collotype
Scope note: This term is a variety of photomechanical process that prints using a process akin to lithography from a surface of light-hardened gelatine.

Label: colour
Scope note: This term is restricted to prints and covers all varieties of prints on which the colour has been printed rather than added by hand to the sheet after it has been printed. It includes both printing from multiple plates and from a single plate coloured 'à la poupée'. The term hand-coloured should be used for prints where the colouring has been added by hand after printing. The term 'colour' should be entered in addition to a print technique in cases where more than one block, plate, stone or screen has been used. N.B. Lithographs solely using the tint-stone for background colour do not qualify as 'colour lithographs'. See also 'woodblock' for Japanese colour sheet prints, which after 1765 are invariably colour woodblock printed.

Label: colour photographic process
Scope note: Use for colour photographs when the precise type of colour photographic process is not known.

Label: comb-washed
Scope note: Comb-washed applies to where a thick wash or slip has been applied to the surface, in which a reserve pattern is created by combing with some form of multiple-toothed tool to form often complex straight and /or wavy patterns.

Label: combined media
Scope note: The term should be used for contemporary works combining several techniques, such as printmaking, drawing, collage, etc. See also the Technique mixed media for the specific printmaking technique, used in Victorian prints.

Label: complex gauze
Scope note: The term is restricted to the Stein Project.

Label: computer-generated
Scope note: This term is mainly used to cover all types of modern printmaking where the image has been generated from a computer rather than by hand; such prints will almost always be laser printed (q.v). For such objects, 'print' should be entered in Object Name and the printing method should be entered in the Description.

Label: copper-plated
Scope note: Enter COPPER in the Material field.

Label: coppered
Scope note: The term refers to the coating of an object in copper by any uncertain process. Enter COPPER in the Material field. See also the term 'copper-plated'.

Label: couched
Scope note: Couching is achieved by holding a cord, braid or a variety of different threads in place with a stitch.

Label: couching stitch
Scope note: The term is restricted to Chinese Stein textiles.

Label: counter-relief
Scope note: The term refers to a form of decoration on Medieval tiles where the design is stamped or impressed into the clay. See also the terms 'impressed' and 'stamped'.

Label: cracked-off
Scope note: Technique by which the rim of a blown glass vesse is created. By using the point of a diamond (or similar sharp stone) and a train of soft glass, the vessel is separated from the 'overblow'. This method is most frequently used in the making of thin-walled vessels, often those which have been blown into moulds (Tait 1991).

Label: crayon-manner
Scope note: This term is a variety of intaglio printmaking that uses specially-designed tools to build on the copper a facsimile of a crayon drawing; such prints are often printed in coloured inks.

Label: creped
Scope note: A technique applied in the 19thC to colour woodblock prints (Asia).

Label: cuenca
Scope note: a mode of decoration on Seville tiles by which the outlines of a design were impressed to keep the coloured glazes from intermingling (Honey).

Label: cuerda seca
Scope note: a pottery technique by which the outlines of a design, drawn with manganese and grease, served to keep the coloured glazes from intermingling (Honey).

Label: cut-pile
Scope note: Cut thread embroidery.

Label: damascened
Scope note: The term refers to a technique applied to metal objects; generally inlaid, but can also refer to etched steel.

Label: damask on plain weave
Scope note: The term is restricted to the Stein Project.

Label: die-stamped
Scope note: The term refers to impressed decoration on metal made with a die.

Label: dobanga
Scope note: Japanese for 'copperplate print'. The technology was first used in Japan in the late 18thC.

Label: double faced weave
Scope note: The term is restricted to the Stein Project.

Label: doucai
Scope note: Doucai (?? ‘joined or interlocking colours’), is a decorative technique in which porcelain painters outlined or half-outlined designs in blue pigment directly on to the biscuit (leather-hard porcelain body). Then they glazed and fired the generally small and delicate cups, bowls and dishes. Next they filled in and added the outlined designs over the glaze with yellow, red, green and aubergine enamel colours and refired them in a muffle kiln at a lower temperature. Potters first used this particular twice-fired technique in the early-fifteenth century but perfected it in the Chenghua era.

Label: drawn
Scope note: This term is a generic term used in the BM to cover all methods of hand-drawing on paper in the Western tradition; it includes watercolour, pen and ink, and graphite. The term 'painted' is used for finished works on paper in the Asiatic schools.

Label: drawn bead
Scope note: Drawn glass beads are made by blowing a bubble into the molten gather or pushing a rod or other tool into the gather, attaching a rod to the opposite end of the gather and gradually pulling into a long continuous tube. This process is exhausting and involves several individuals over the course of several hours. The bubble forms the hollow centre and the tube is cut into lengths of about a metre which are then assigned to other workers who chop the tubes into small individual beads. The beads are usually heat-treated in order to finish the sharp ends: this is done by packing them in ash or sand to minimise them sticking together when they are re-heated and stirring them until the ends become smooth and rounded. They are then cleaned, sorted by size where necessary and in recent times were threaded for sale according to the weight of the bunch. This term has only been used in a small proportion of the bead records.

Label: drypoint
Scope note: This term is a variety of intaglio printmaking in which the plate is directly scored with a sharp needle; it is often combined with etching on a single plate.

Label: dust-pressed
Scope note: The action of forming a tile from dust clay in a press which compacted the clay between two dies. (Austwick 1980).

Label: ebonised
Scope note: Darkening wood to create the appearance of ebony.

Label: electroformed
Scope note: The term refers to the production of metal copies of an original by an electrochemical process (generally referred to as electroforming), a basic plating process (mainly copper) aided by an electrical source, in which metal ions migrate from an anode and are 'deposited' onto the surface of a mould (cathode) gradually building to take the form and detail of the original. The term 'electrotype' is entered as an Object Name, as well as the Object Name of the original. See Object Name 'electrotype' for a definition of that term and its use in the British Museum records.

Label: electroplated
Scope note: This term refers to the deposition of a layer of metal by electrolysis; if known to be silver enter SILVER to the Material field, otherwise enter METAL (or a more appropriate NT).

Label: electrostatic process
Scope note: The term refers to the process patented under the name ‘xerography’, and other forms of copying using electrically charged particles.

Label: embossed
Scope note: The term should not be used for the print technique referred to as EMBOSSING.

Label: embossing
Scope note: The term is a printmaking method in which a design is impressed into paper without the use of any ink.

Label: enamelled
Scope note: This term is only used in the context of metalwork, and the Material 'enamel' is entered for such records. - The only exception is for European Iron Age material, where the Technique 'enamelled' is entered, but not the Material 'enamel' (See the Scope Note for the Material term 'enamel'). - If the object is simply a sample of enamel, the Technique 'enamelled' is not entered. N.B. The term 'enamelled' is not used in the context of ceramics, where the object is described as, e.g.: 'painted in enamels', or 'decorated in enamels' (with the resulting Techniques 'glazed' and painted') and no entry 'enamel' in Material'.

Label: engine-turned
Scope note: The technique refers to the engraving of patterns upon metals by machinery. (OED)

Label: engraved
Scope note: This term is used to cover directly incised surfaces. In the context of Early Medieval material, the term refers to decoration, lettering, deliberate marks and signs, etc. cut into the surface of an object, generally to some depth and width. It also refers to incising designs in metal, wood, etc. for reproduction by printing.

Label: engraving
Scope note: This term is a printmaking method, a variety of intaglio printmaking, in which the lines on a metal plate are cut using a v-shaped tool called a burin.

Label: erratic-tempered
Scope note: P&E

Label: etched
Scope note: Use for three-dimensional objects only. For prints, use ETCHING.

Label: etching
Scope note: This term is a printmaking method, a variety of intaglio printmaking, in which the lines are bitten by acid into a metal plate.

Label: faceted
Scope note: The term is used in the context of glass bead production. It has only been entered in a small proportion of the bead records.

Label: feldspar-tempered
Scope note: Feldspar is a name given to a group of minerals, usually white or flesh-red in colour, occurring in crystals or in crystalline masses. They consist of a silicate of alumina with soda, potash, lime, etc.

Label: filed
Scope note: Only use the term when the technique is of significance.

Label: fired
Scope note: For Middle East this term is used to describe the deliberate hardening of clay or composite materials through heating in a kiln. It is distinct from baking which is at a lower temperature or accidental (see 'baked').

Label: flaked
Scope note: refers to stone fractured to give a sharp edge.

Label: flashed
Scope note: Technique whereby glass of one colour is fused onto the outer surface of glass of a different colour, by taking a gather of the inner colour - sometimes partly inflated - and dipping it into a crucible containing molten glass od the outer colour. By repeating the procedure, a multicoloured layered glass can be produced (Tait 1991).

Label: folded
Scope note: Only use the term if it the technique was used in the manufacture of the object.

Label: folded bead
Scope note: The term refers to a technique for making beads which involved heating one or more small flat pieces of glass, bending them over a piece of wire and gently heating the junction(s) to fuse the edges: they may be recognised by this seam-like junction which runs parallel with the perforation. They are typically made from one piece of glass and therefore have a single seam (hence known as single-strip folded beads) but others are made by fusing two pieces of glass and therefore have two seams (double-strip folded beads). This is likely to be a very old tradition within the Middle East and is related to winding. This term has only been used in a small proportion of the bead records.

Label: folded silk
Scope note: Starched, folded rectangles of silk, sewn together to form geometric flower- and gem- like designs. This decorative technique is found on many Miao (Hmong) textiles.

Label: fused
Scope note: Only use the term when it refers to a process in the manufacture of the object.

Label: gauffrage
Scope note: [Blind-printing] Design impressed without the use of ink, to create textural effects; used primarily for East Asian prints. NT gauffrage

Label: gilded
Scope note: The term 'gilded' refers to an overlay (wholly or in parts) of a thin layer of gold. The term 'gold' is entered in the Materials field as well as terms for the base Materials. 'Silver-gilt' refers to a silver base to which a layer of gilding has been applied, and the Technique entered is 'gilded', the Materials 'silver' and 'gold'. See also the term 'gold-plated'.

Label: glazed
Scope note: There are instances where objects which are decorated with underglaze are not glazed, but they are uncommon. N.B. The Technique ‘glazed’ never applies to ancient Greek pottery, meaning pottery produced throughout all periods from the Aegean (or Greek) Neolithic to the Hellenistic periods. N.B. The term 'black glaze' is used for Greek pottery which is covered in a clay slip that turns a glossy black during firing. In such instances, the Technique is 'slipped' and not 'glazed', even if the term ‘glazed’ may appear in the Description to designate areas of ‘black glaze’.

Label: glued
Scope note: Only use the term when it refers to a process in the manufacture of the object.

Label: glyphograph
Scope note: This term is a method (patented in 1842) of creating a relief printing block by drawing through a compostion on a metal plate, and making an electrotype of the result.

Label: gold-plated
Scope note: Enter GOLD in the Material field. See also the term 'gilded'.

Label: granulated
Scope note: The technique of roughening the internal or external surface of a pot by applying sand before firing.

Label: guri
Scope note: A form of carved lacquer where alternate layers of different- coloured lacquers are carved in schematised spiral scrolls. The deeply cut lines are often bevelled. (Rawson 1992).

Label: gypsograph
Scope note: This term is a method (patented in 1837) of creating a relief printing block by drawing through a block of plaster mounted on a metal base, and making an elctrotype of the result.

Label: hand-coloured
Scope note: The term is restricted to prints where the colouring has been added by hand after printing. The term 'colour' should be used when the work has been printed in coloured inks.

Label: handmade
Scope note: Use only for ceramic objects which are not wheel-made. For the Middle East Department the details of how a pot was hand-made (e.g. slabbed, coiled, etc.) will be entered in the Description field. This term can be used in conjunction with WHEEL-FINISHED, for example to describe a coiled pot finished on a tournette.

Label: hiramakie
Scope note: Technique, introduced in the Kamakura period, where sprinkled powders are applied directly on a smooth lacquered surface in very low relief so that only the thickness of the final protective lacquer coating is raised above the surface. (Dictionary of Japanese Architectural and Art Historical Terminology, JAANUS)

Label: hmanzi-shwecha
Scope note: The term refers to relief decoration made of lacquer putty (thayo) and set with glass spangles.

Label: impressed
Scope note: See also 'stamped' and, for tiles, 'counter-relief'.

Label: incised
Scope note: In the context of Early Medieval material, the term refers to decoration, lettering, deliberate marks, etc. cut into the surface of an object, generally fairly lightly and not very deeply.

Label: intaglio
Scope note: This term is used for engraving on seals and gems; not for printmaking.

Label: intaglio print
Scope note: This term is used for the class of printmaking using metal plates inked so as to print from the incisions (lines or dots) rather than the surface. Use whenever possible a more specific term. Only use this term when the method is unclear or when numerous varieties of method are used on a single plate. For three-dimensional objects use INTAGLIO.

Label: ishizuri-e
Scope note: Japanese woodblock print employing white lines on a black background in imitation of stone rubbings.

Label: jin in plain weave
Scope note: The term refers to warp faced compound plain weave.

Label: jin in twill
Scope note: The term refers to warp faced compound twill.

Label: joggled
Scope note: The term is restricted to the slip decoration technique.

Label: kalamkari
Scope note: The term refers to a technique of painting and dyeing on cloth using a distinctive pen.

Label: katakiribori
Scope note: Decorative technique for metalwork where design is carved with single strokes of a square chisel held at an angle.

Label: khari
Scope note: The term refers to an Indian textile technique whereby gold spangled decoration is applied with glue to cloth.

Label: kinrande
Scope note: Japanese name for the gold color added to Chinese 'wucai' porcelain, featuring a white-base with red, green and yellow motifs, made in Ming-dynasty China. (Dictionary of Japanese Architectural and Art Historical Terminology, JAANUS)

Label: kirikane
Scope note: Decorative technique on Japanese paintings and lacquer objects of applied strips of cut gold leaf.

Label: kundekari
Scope note: The term refers to the technique of putting gold and silver onto steel arms and armour (a type of overlay).

Label: lac burgaute
Scope note: East Asian lacquer technique, inlaid with mother-of-pearl and sometimes gold or silver.

Label: lacquered
Scope note: For the Asian collections, objects described as 'lacquer' imply the technique of lacquer application on a substrate, and should have Technique 'lacquered'. Enter the Material 'lacquer (ie. tree resin)' or 'lac' (ie. insect secretion), depending on circumstance. Many objects from South Asia with 'lacquer' in Material may in fact be lacquered using lac. See also LACQUERED in the Techniques field. As a general rule, lacquered objects from the Middle East and South Asia are made using 'lac', while those from South East Asia and the far East are made using 'lacquer'. See also LACQUER and LAC in the Materials field.

Label: leaf-gilded
Scope note: Enter GOLD in the Material field. Not all records with references to 'gold leaf' have 'leaf-gilded' as a Technique. See also the Materials thesaurus.

Label: liao samite
Scope note: The term refers to compound twill weft faced on both sides.

Label: line-impressed
Scope note: The term refers to a stamped linear design on a Medieval tile.

Label: linocut
Scope note: This term is a relief printmaking process similar to woodcut, but using a sheet of linoleum in place of wooden block.

Label: lithograph
Scope note: This term is a planographic printmaking process, using a stone or metal surface. It relies on the antipathy of grease and water to enable a drawn design to be used to make a print from.

Label: loomwoven
Scope note: Beadwork or quillwork woven in a strip on a bow loom made from withe or stick.

Label: looped
Scope note: The term is used in the context of string-work, e.g. for string bags.

Label: lost-wax cast
Scope note: A method of casting which involves making a wax model, sometimes with a core of another substance, enclosing the model in a mould, melting away the wax, and pouring molten metal or glass into the void resulting from the removal of the wax, then allowing the material to harden to harden before removing the mould. The final stage after casting usually entails polishing of the finished object.

Label: low relief
Scope note: This term is for use with three-dimensional objects

Label: luted
Scope note: The term generally refers to green-hard handles, spouts, knobs, etc., being stuck on using a little slip as adhesive, as opposed to those applied and smoothed. This distinction is not always adhered to.

Label: maki-e
Scope note: Japanese decorative technique of metal dust sprinkled onto lacquer before it is set, and sometimes repeated in layers.

Label: marvered
Scope note: Applied to a shaping process of glass manufacture in which molten glass is rolled smooth on a polished surface.

Label: medal engraving
Scope note: This term is a printmaking method invented in 1831 that reproduces in two dimensions the design on a coin or medal by using a tracing machine.

Label: metalcut
Scope note: This term is a relief printmaking method, printing from the surface of a metal plate; used in XVc often decorating the surface of the plate with punched holes (hence the term manière criblée - sieved manner')

Label: mezzotint
Scope note: This term is an intaglio printmaking process which works from dark to light by smoothing down with a burnisher the surface of a roughened metal plate.

Label: mica-dusted
Scope note: Surface treatment used on Romano-British and Iron Age pottery.

Label: millefiori
Scope note: A term used to describe the technology whereby objects are embedded with thinly sliced sections of glass canes of multicoloured chevron, floral or other patterns in alternating concentric bands (Tait 1991).

Label: minakari
Scope note: The term refers to enamelled work on metal in Iran and North India (associated especially with Jaipur in Rajasthan). The term 'enamel' should be entered in the Materials field. .

Label: mixed media
Scope note: The term refers to printmaking resulting from a single plates incorporating various intaglio techniques, a process used for Victorian prints. Double-key with the individual print techniques if known.

Label: modelled
Scope note: The term refers to modelling by hand, and should not be used for objects which happen to be models, unless the technique is specifically referred to. NB. MODELLED, MOULD-MADE and MOULDED have been used interchangeably in some cases.

Label: monotype
Scope note: This term is a type of drawing in which printing ink is transferred to the paper from another surface. This can be done drectly, by offsetting a composition from a glass or metal plate, or indirectly by tracing through from one sheet to another via a sheet of carbon paper or similar. Monotypes are classified as prints rather than drawings.

Label: mould-made
Scope note: The Middle East Department use MOULD-MADE in preference to MODELLED, MOULDED, etc. However in other departments, MODELLED, MOULD-MADE and MOULDED have been used interchangeably in some cases.

Label: moulded
Scope note: If the object is MOULD-MADE, use that term instead. For Prehistory & Europe, see MOULDING in the Form field. NB. The terms MOULD-MADE, MODELLED AND MOULDED have been used interchangeably in some cases.

Label: nailed
Scope note: Only use the term when the technique is of significance.

Label: nanako
Scope note: Pattern of small dots (thought to resemble fish-roe) beaten out with an indented chisel, usually used as a background pattern on metal fittings (kanagu). (Dictionary of Japanese Architectural and Art Historical Terminology, JAANUS)

Label: nashiji
Scope note: Literally, 'pear-skin ground'; name given to two widely-used techniques invented in the Kamakura period. In one, large irregular shaped gold flakes are scattered at differing angles in many layers in wet 'nashiji urushi', a highly translucent lacquer that has been tinted orange; a further coating is applied and polishing exposes the flakes to produce an uneven surface texture. This technique is often used to give a uniformly decorative surface to large but less important areas, such as the interior of drawers or the underside of boxes. In the other, a fine metallic powder is sprinkled onto a lacquered surface; when dry, a coat of transparent lacquer is applied and lightly polished. (Dictionary of Japanese Architectural and Art Historical Terminology, JAANUS)

Label: nickel-plated
Scope note: Enter NICKEL in the Material field.

Label: nielloed
Scope note: Enter NIELLO in the Materials field.

Label: nishiki-e
Scope note: Japanese full colour woodblock prints, first perfected in Edo in 1764-1765.

Label: oleograph
Scope note: This term is a variety of chromolithograph which is treated with a layer of varnish to give the effect of an oil painting.

Label: open-bite
Scope note: This term is used for the direct biting by acid of localised areas of a plate, when no design has previously been fixed to the plate.

Label: opus interrasile
Scope note: A form of open-work in which holes are pierced in sheet-metal with a chisel to produce a design.

Label: oxidised
Scope note: Only use the term when the process was intentional, rather than accidental.

Label: painted
Scope note: A term that covers all types of painting in oils and fresco, and also finished works on silk or paper of the schools of Asia. For Western traditions of art, the word 'drawn' has been used for works on paper, including watercolours. N.B. The term is also used in the context of ceramics, where the object is described as, e.g.: 'painted in overglaze enamels', or 'decorated in overglaze enamels' (with the resulting Techniques 'glazed' and painted' and Material 'enamel'). For ceramics in the Greek and Roman Department, the term painted is also to be used in the sense of ‘decorated’. The composition of the ‘paint’, which can often be described as a ‘slip’ is irrelevant. Thus the term 'slip-painted' is not used for ceramics in that Department, and 'slipped' or 'painted' are used instead.

Label: paperblock
Scope note: A planographic print technique.

Label: parcel-gilded
Scope note: Enter GOLD in the Material field.

Label: paste print
Scope note: This term refers to a rare type of XVc object related to a woodcut, in which a layer of paste was spread on a sheet of paper and covered with a sheet of tin foil. The design was printed on top of the foil in ink from a woodcut so that the foil presented a glittering background (now usually degraded).

Label: pate-sur-pate
Scope note: A form of decoration in which a relief pattern is built up by repeated applications of thin white slip. (Austwick 1980).

Label: photographic process
Scope note: This term is a general term used to cover all types of photograph. Whenever possible use one of the narrower terms of photography.

Label: photogravure
Scope note: This term is a photomechanical process of printmaking, in which a photographic image is transferred to a metal plate that is then printed in intaglio (qv)

Label: photolithograph
Scope note: This term is a photomechanical process of printmaking, in which a photographic image is transferred to a stone or metal surface that is then printed lithographically

Label: photomechanical print
Scope note: This term is a general term used to cover all types of printmaking based on photographic images. Whenever possible use one of the narrower terms

Label: photorelief
Scope note: This term is a photomechanical process of printmaking, in which a photographic image is transferred to a metal surface that is then printed in relief. These prints may be line-blocks or half-tones (rephotographed through a screen). This was the standard method of illustrating books in the era of letterpress.

Label: pillar-moulded
Scope note: A technique of either casting or blowing glass into a specially formed mould to create ribbed "pillars" round the sides of a vessel.

Label: pincered
Scope note: The technique of shaping soft glass by manipulating it with pincers. It is used for making entirely functional - or perhaps structural - elements of an object, and also for purely decorative ones (Tait 1991).

Label: pinched
Scope note: The term is used for glass and metal, as well as pottery.

Label: piqué
Scope note: A system of decoration using specially made pins on watch cases and boxes which usually have a covering of turtle-shell (tortoise-shell), leather or fish skin (shagreen). As well as acting as a decorative element, the pins also serve to fixing the covering on the metal carcass of the case. The pins are generally arranged in floral patterns, but can also take the form of coronets, animals and birds. In more sophisticated examples pictorial representations are made up using pins and larger engraved pieces of metal and wires inlaid into the surface - a technique known as piqué posé.

Label: planographic print
Scope note: This term is a general term used to cover the processes of printmaking (basically the lithographic group) that print from the surface rather than in relief or intaglio.

Label: plated
Scope note: Plating is a term generally used for any of the methods of applying a surface layer of another metal onto a metal substrate, including those used in Antiquity.

Label: plique-à-jour
Scope note: The term 'enamel' should be entered as a Material.

Label: pressure flaked
Scope note: Flaking technique used in the knapping of flint.

Label: printed
Scope note: This term is used to cover all methods of printing onto paper or other flat surfaces where the precise technique was not clear when writing the catalogue entry

Label: punched
Scope note: This term is a method of decorating surfaces with a pointed tool.

Label: pyro-decorated
Scope note: Used to describe technique of blackening without engraving.

Label: qiang jin
Scope note: technique whereby incised lines are filled with gold; only on lacquer.

Label: re-blown
Scope note: Term used to describe glass-blowing technique where the vessel is re-inflated after dipping into a patterned mould.

Label: relief etching
Scope note: This term is a variety of relief printmaking, where instead of being cut away with the knife, the background is eaten away by acid,

Label: relief print
Scope note: This term is a general term to cover all varieties of relief printmaking. Whenever possible use one of the narrower terms.

Label: resist-smoked
Scope note: To be narrow term of smoked

Label: retouched
Scope note: The term is used for flint and stone objects.

Label: ribbed
Scope note: The creation of a series of ridges by incising to create relief.

Label: ripple flaked
Scope note: Flaking technique used in the knapping of flint.

Label: riveted
Scope note: Only use the term when the technique is of special significance.

Label: rocker-worked
Scope note: The term applies to the technique of incising a line with a twisting action to produce a zigzag effect.

Label: rod-formed
Scope note: The term refers to a glass-making technique.

Label: rouletted
Scope note: This term is a method of decorating surfaces.

Label: rubbing
Scope note: This term is a methof of recording a carved design in low relief by rubbing over a sheet of paper placed on top with a soft pencil, crayon or chalk

Label: samite
Scope note: The term refers to weft faced compound twill. The term is restricted to the Stein Project.

Label: sanded
Scope note: Use when a pottery vessel is rolled in sand to make a decorative surface

Label: sandwiched
Scope note: The term refers to a technique whereby decoration is introduced between two layers of glass (Tait 1991).

Label: satin
Scope note: Satin is a weave structure and so is included, like 'velvet', in the Techniques rather than Materials thesaurus. Both terms, however, are commonly used to describe what an object is made of (or a support). Although in the case of satin, the lustrous effect is often made using silk thread, other fibres can also be used.

Label: satin samite
Scope note: The term refers to weft faced compound satin.

Label: sawn
Scope note: Only enter the term when the technique was used in the manufacture of the object.

Label: screenprint
Scope note: This term is a method of printmaking using a fine mesh through which the ink is forced onto paper. A design may be attached to the mesh by a stencil, or by stopping-out manually or via a photographic process (hence the term photoscreenprint, which is not here distinguished from other methods of screenprinting).

Label: seal-impressed
Scope note: For objects that have been deliberately impressed with a seal. The term 'seal-impression' should be entered in Object Name.

Label: self-slip
Scope note: Finely textured surfaces that appear to be slipped with the same material that constitutes the clay body, distinct slip is difficult to determine and could have resulted from wiping the surfaces with a wet hand.

Label: sgraffito
Scope note: A technique of decorating pottery in which a layer of slip is scored through to reveal the contrasting ground underneath (see Hodges).

Label: shishiaibori
Scope note: Decorative technique of sunken relief carving.

Label: shwe zawa
Scope note: The term refers to a technique of laying gold leaf on lacquered surface.

Label: silver-plated
Scope note: Enter SILVER in the Material field. See also the term 'silvered'.

Label: silvered
Scope note: The term refers to the coating of an object in silver by any uncertain process. Add SILVER to the Material field. See also SILVER-LEAF in Materials. See also the term 'silver-plated'.

Label: slip-combed
Scope note: The term refers to the technique of applying slip with a comb.

Label: slip-feathered
Scope note: The term refers to the technique of applying slip with a feather.

Label: slip-painted
Scope note: Slip-painted is a term typically used where a coloured slip has been applied to create decoration. The term 'slip-painted' is not used for ceramics in the Greek and Roman Department, where the term 'slipped’ is used when the object is slipped but otherwise undecorated, and the term ‘painted’ is used in the sense of ‘decorated’. The term ‘slip-painted’ is avoided in this context to avoid confusion between 'painted' and 'slipped' because what is usually referred to as ‘paint’ could be described as a ‘slip’ in terms of composition, or vice versa.

Label: slipped
Scope note: Slipped applies to where the surface has been covered (either dipped or block covered) with a fine clay ('slip') to give it extra fineness of appearance or to change its colour, particularly if then covered with a transparent glaze and then incised (sgraffiato technique). Slip-painted is a term typically used where a coloured slip has been applied to create decoration but this term is not used for ceramics in the Greek and Roman Department, where the term 'slipped’ is used when the object is slipped but otherwise undecorated, and the term ‘painted’ is used in the sense of ‘decorated’. The term ‘slip-painted’ should be avoided in this context to avoid confusion between 'painted' and 'slipped' because what is usually referred to as ‘paint’ could be described as a ‘slip’ in terms of composition, or vice versa.

Label: slumped
Scope note: The process of heating glass until gravity forces it to conform to the shape of the form (heat-resistant object used to create the final shape) on which it rests (Tait 1991).

Label: soft-ground etching
Scope note: This term is a method of printmaking in which a drawing is made on a sheet of paper on a soft etching ground, pulled off, and the resulting design transferred to the plate by etching

Label: spattered
Scope note: A technique generally applied to glassware.

Label: spinning
Scope note: The term is restricted to metalwork. See also SPUN.

Label: splashed
Scope note: A term widely used in literature on pottery techniques. It refers to coloured pigment applied under a glaze which has run and dispersed during the firing. This term does not apply to unglazed pots from Ancient Egypt, which have occasionally also been described as 'splashed', but which have been quite literally splashed with colour, probably by shaking it off a reed brush.

Label: sprang
Scope note: The term refers to a form of warp manipulation that can be either interlinked, interlaced or intertwined.

Label: spun
Scope note: The term is restricted to textiles. See also SPINNING.

Label: stamped
Scope note: This term is used for stamping used to decorate surfaces of objects, not for printmaking. See also 'impressed' and, for tiles, 'counter-relief'.

Label: stencil printing
Scope note: This term is a simple method of printmaking, using pigment brushed through stencils onto paper.Printing thriough stencils can be used to create the entire design or to add colouring to a monochrome deisgn. For Prints & Drawings, use the term for early stencil colouring, for modern pochoir processes and for monochrome roneo prints.

Label: stencilled
Scope note: This term is a method of decorating surfaces. Do not use this term for prints - see STENCIL.

Label: stipple
Scope note: This term is a variety of intaglio printmaking in which the tone is created by making numerous dots on the plate, either directly or via etching.

Label: stippled
Scope note: This term is a method of decorating surfaces. For prints, use STIPPLE.

Label: stonecut
Scope note: The stonecut print, a technique used by the Inuit in northern Canada, particularly in the Cape Dorset region, is a variation on the woodcut, using stone instead of wood as the matrix. The design, which is raised, is inked and a thin sheet of paper, usually mulberry paper, is placed over the inked surface. A protective sheet is placed over this thin sheet, and the paper is then pressed gently against the stone by hand with a small padded disc.Colour can be added using a stencil.

Label: struck
Scope note: This term should not be entered for coins, as it is assumed. If a coin is cast, enter 'cast' in Description and Technique.

Label: sumizuri-e
Scope note: Early Japanese monochrome woodblock print in sumi (ink).

Label: supplementary warp
Scope note: A structural weaving term unique to the Andes.

Label: supplementary weft
Scope note: A structural weaving term unique to the Andes.

Label: takamakie
Scope note: Japanese decorative technique, developed in the Muromachi period, where metallic powders are applied to soft surface designs built up through a mixture of lacquer and charcoal or clay dust. They are affixed by a protective lacquer coat and polished. (Dictionary of Japanese Architectural and Art Historical Terminology, JAANUS)

Label: tan-e
Scope note: Japanese woodblock prints hand-coloured with an orange-red pigment, produced from the late 17th century to the first quarter of the 18th century. (Encyclopedia Britannica)

Label: tapestry
Scope note: Kesi means silk tapestry and is not a technique as such, but refers to the finished product.

Label: taqueté
Scope note: The term refers to weft faced compound tabby.

Label: tatted
Scope note: The term refers to a technique used to produce a specific type of meshwork lace made by looping and knotting a length of thread using a small shuttle.

Label: tempera
Scope note: This term is a method of painting using egg-yolk as the binding medium for the pigment. (See Thompson, D V, (tr.) 1960. Cennino d'Andrea Cennini's The Craftsman's Handbook (Il libro dell'arte) 2nd edn. New York: Dover.)

Label: tempered
Scope note: This term refers to a technique in metalwork as well as ceramics (for which there are several NTs). Use the Materials field to narrow any searches.

Label: termite-hollowed
Scope note: Indigenous Australians used termites to hollow out didjeridus.

Label: tin-plated
Scope note: In modern manufacturing, tin-plating is usually the application of a thin layer of tin by electro-plating onto iron to make things like tin cans, (and the same method is also used for silver-plating and gold-plating). The term 'tin' should be entered as a Material. See also the term 'tinned'.

Label: tinned
Scope note: Tinned (or tinning) refers to a technique in which a thin layer of tin is applied to an otherwise non-tin item to give it an impression of being made of silver. Another use is to coat the inside of copper vessels to prevent poisoning by copper salts. The term 'tin' is entyered as an additional Material. See also the Technique term 'tin-plated'.

Label: tinted
Scope note: The term is restricted to two-dimensional objects, but is not to be used for Prints & Drawings.

Label: togidashi maki-e
Scope note: Variety of the 'maki-e' decorative technique in lacquer, first popular in the Heian period. After hardening, the low relief sprinkled design and ground were covered in transparent or black lacquer, then polished down with charcoal until the design was flush with the new ground. (Dictionary of Japanese Architectural and Art Historical Terminology, JAANUS)

Label: tooled
Scope note: This term has been used in the context of leatherwork or glass.

Label: trailed
Scope note: Process whereby a strand of glass is pulled directly onto the surface of an object from a relatively large mass of soft glass. It is used to produce spiral, circular or meandering patterns. The trailed glass can subsequently be pincered etc. into other shapes (Tait 1991).

Label: transfer-printed
Scope note: The term is restricted to ceramics.

Label: tsuishu
Scope note: Lacquer technique, literally 'piled cinnabar', where layers of red lacquer are carved in elaborate designs; became the special preserve of a family (whose members each took the name Tsuishu Youzei) which continued over twenty generations from the 15th century to the 20th century, working for the Ashikaga and then Tokugawa shoguns. (Dictionary of Japanese Architectural and Art Historical Terminology, JAANUS)

Label: tube-lined
Scope note: A decorative technique in which raised seams of clay are applied which separate areas of coloured glazes. (Austwick 1980).

Label: turned
Scope note: Use ENGINE-TURNED or LATHE-TURNED if more appropriate.

Label: twill weave
Scope note: The Technique 'weft faced compound twill' is recorded, where identified, in the Description.

Label: twined basketry
Scope note: A technique used in basketry.

Label: urushi-e
Scope note: Japanese hand-coloured woodblock print which imitated the appearance of black lacquer by applying glue to areas printed in black ink.

Label: wheel-finished
Scope note: The term may refer to finishing off on a slow wheel, for hand-made vessels. The Middle East Department use the term to describe vessels finished on a 'proper' wheel, and also on a tournette; the distinction between the type of wheel used will be made in the Description field. This term can be used in conjunction with HAND-MADE, for example to describe a coiled pot finished on a tournette.

Label: wheel-made
Scope note: For the Middle East Department, wheel-made is an archaeological term used for any vessels thrown wholly or partly on a wheel, with no distinction between fast and slow, and should be used in preference to the term WHEEL-THROWN. For the Department of Asia, the Technique is assumed and therefore not specified; HAND-MADE or MOULDED should be entered if relevant.

Label: wood-engraving
Scope note: This term is a variety of relief printmaking using a wooden block, into which lines have been cut using a burin or other fine-pointed tool. The distinction between wood-engraving and woodcut is between hard end-grain wood (usually boxwood) cut across the grain with engraving tools (wood-engraving), and soft-grain wood cut along the grain with a knife and gouge (woodcut). With Japanese prints, the term 'woodblock' is traditionally used in preference to ''woodcut'. The type of wood used for woodcut/woodblock is always a soft wood: in Japan it is usually cherry, in the West pear, lime wood or similar.

Label: woodblock
Scope note: In relation to Japan, the term 'woodblock' is used in preference to 'woodcut', and this reflects a difference in techniques employed and aesthetic effects produced. The type of wood also varies, as in Japan cherry wood is used, whereas in the West it is usually pear, lime wood or similar.

Label: woodcut
Scope note: This term is a variety of relief printmaking using a wooden block, from which the background is cut away leaving the design standing in relief to be inked and printed. The distinction between wood-engraving and woodcut is between hard end-grain wood (usually boxwood) cut across the grain with engraving tools (wood-engraving), and soft-grain wood cut along the grain with a knife and gouge (woodcut). With Japanese prints, the term 'woodblock' is traditionally used in preference to ''woodcut'. The type of wood used for woodcut/woodblock is always a soft wood: in Japan it is usually cherry, in the West pear, lime wood or similar. A chiaroscuro woodcut is a variety of colour woodcut printed in tones of one colour; each tone is printed from a separate block.

Label: worked
Scope note: Use only in Prehistoric context.

Label: wound
Scope note: This is the earliest known technique for making glass beads and similar objects such as spindle-whorls and entails dipping a lightly tapered thin metal rod known as a mandrel into a crucible containing molten glass inside the furnace. The mandrel is spun in order to build up a molten glass thread around the end: the object is then shaped or decorated by pressing against a flat or moulded surface or by impressing it with a paddle. Trails of a different colour can be easily applied at this stage. The mandrel cools and shrinks faster than the glass and therefore can be easily removed, leaving a slightly conical hole with bubbles orientated around the perforation, and the object is then allowed to cool slowly in an annealing chamber. This term has only been used in a small proportion of the object records.

Label: woven
Scope note: Apart from the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas, this technique is generally assumed for textiles and is not entered in the Techniques field unless specified in the documentation. Hand-woven is assumed (as opposed to commercially produced). It is only specified in the Description if the context is unusual. See also basketry.

Label: wucai
Scope note: Wucai (?? ‘five colours’) is a twice-fired technique composed of underglaze blue and overglaze red, yellow, and green.

Label: yun
Scope note: A Burmese lacquer technique, involving engraving and then colouring.

Label: zogan
Scope note: Technique of inlay on Japanese metalwork.
The term refers to split stitch.
For works on paper.
The term refers to dyed.
The term is restricted to textiles.
The term refers to clamp-resist dyed silk.
The term refers to brocade.
The term refers to wool tabby.
The term refers to jin silk in plain weave (warp faced compound tabby)
The term refers to taquete (weft faced compound tabby).
The term refers to satin stitch.
The term refers to jin-silk in twill (warp faced compound twill).
The term refers to samite (weft faced compound twill).
The term refers to monochrome woven silk.
The term refers to knotted.
The term refers to ash-resist dyed silk.
The term refers to lampas.
The term refers to gauze.
The term refers to non-pattern woven, ie. woven without pattern.
The term refets to tie-dyed silk.
The term refers to silk tabby.
The term refers to damask on plain weave.
The term refers to twill damask.
The term refers to kesi (tapestry).
The term refers to satin damask.
The term refers to satin samite (weft faced compound satin).
Chinese textiles
The term refers to twine-woven.
Hand-woven (constructed textile without loom)
The term refers to fine polychrome woven.
The term refers to complex gauze.
The term refers to wax-resist dyed silk.
The term refers to Liao samite (compound twill weft faced on both sides).
The term refers to couching stitch.
The term refers to polychrome woven silk.
The term refrs to chain stitch.
The term refers to double weave.
The term refers to double faced weave.
